review.title: Approximate Probabilistic Inference via Word-Level Counting
review.abstract: Hashing-based model counting has emerged as a promising approach for large-scale probabilistic inference on graphical models. A key component of these techniques is the use of xor-based 2-universal hash functions that operate over Boolean domains. Many counting problems arising in probabilistic inference are, however, naturally encoded over finite discrete domains. Techniques based on bit-level (or Boolean) hash functions require these problems to be propositionalized, making it impossible to leverage the remarkable progress made in SMT (Satisfiability Modulo Theory) solvers that can reason directly over words (or bit-vectors). In this work, we present the first approximate model counter that uses word-level hashing functions, and can directly leverage the power of sophisticated SMT solvers. Empirical evaluation over an extensive suite of benchmarks demonstrates the promise of the approach.

sections.heading: 4 Word-level Hash Function
sections.text: The performance of hashing-based functions for approximate counting depends crucially on the underlying family of hash functions used to partition the solution space.

sections.heading: 5 Algorithm
sections.text: We present SMTApproxMC, a word-level hashing-based counting.The seudo-cell code is a technical algorithm that returns as input a formula F into the theory of fixed-wide words, a tolerance ε (> 0) and a confidence threshold 1 (0, 1), an estimate of SMTApproxMC into the solution space of SMT cells of approximately the same size, assuming the formula F of n variables, each width k, in their support. The central idea of SMTApproxMC is to randomly partition the solution space of F into "small" cells of approximately the same size, using word-level hash functions of HSMT (n, C), where C is calculated step by step. The check for "small" -ness of cells is performed using a word-level SMT solver.

sections.heading: 6 Experimental Methodology and Results
sections.text: To evaluate the performance and effectiveness of SMTApxMC, we have built a prototype implementation and conducted extensive experiments. Our set of benchmarks consisted of more than 150 problems arising from different areas such as circuit thinking, planning, program synthesis and the like. sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: Hashing-based model counting has emerged as a promising approach for probabilistic conclusions on graphical models. While real-world examples naturally have word-level constraints, modern approximate model counters effectively reduce the problem to propositional model counting due to the lack of non-bit-level hash functions. In this paper, we introduced HSMT, a word-level hash function, and used it to build SMTApproxMC, an approximate word-level model counter. Our experiments show that SMTApproxMC techniques are bit-level hashing. Our study also points to interesting directions for future work. For example, the adaptation of SMTApproxMC to SMT solution strategies and the augmentation of SMT solution strategies to efficiently establish hash functions used in counting are exciting clues for future work. Our work goes far beyond replacing other risk-based SMT counters with building blocks that may also be considered to be more efficient.
